Package gnu.cajo.invoke

This package is the foundation for transparent local/remote inter-VM communication.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Invoke The generic inter-component communication interface, and foundation for this paradigm.
RemoteInvoke The Remote Component Communication Interface, and reason for this package.
 

Class Summary
Client This class is used to create a hosting VM to receive graphical proxy objects from a remote VMs.
NoSecurityManager This utility class creates a trivial SecurityManager for developing proxy hosting clients.
Remote This utility class takes a object, and allows it to be called from remote VMs.
 

Package gnu.cajo.invoke Description

This package is the foundation for transparent local/remote inter-VM communication. It provides a standard local/remote interface between components, and prevents having to generate unique RMI stubs for every application specific remote class.

The rationale behind this paradim is to enable seamless and dynamic linking between remote and local items, in order to accomplish advanced functionality. Items can also be mobile, moving from one VM to another, even providing graphical user interfaces to itself on remote hosts having video capability. It is designed to harness the power of such concepts as scale-free networking, and the emergent behavior of a collective network.

For the purposes of this paradigm, any object implementing the invoke interface is considered an Item. If a VM allows the loading of remote code, and an item is sent to it, that item is referred to as a Proxy.

This package must always be local to any client, and therefore would never be included in a proxy's codebase jar file. This is to reduce the proxy's codebase size, while at the same time, create a level of development standardization.

Also included in the package is a client application/applet. While not strictly necessary, it provides another standard paradigm for creating and using graphical proxy items. It could be compared to a next-generation X-client, but is much more capable, being able to perform general purpose computation on the client.
